title: 107_hr542
content: The Act titled "Small Business Review Panel Technical Amendments Act of 1999" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 outlines the findings and purposes of the Act. The Congress finds that a vibrant small business sector is crucial for job creation in the economy, with small businesses facing a disproportionate share of regulatory burdens. Federal agencies need to consider the impact of regulations on small businesses early in the rulemaking process. The Small Business Advocacy Review Panel process, established by the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act of 1996, allows small businesses to participate in developing rules effectively. The Small Business Advocacy Review Panel process, established by the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act of 1996, allows small businesses to participate in developing rules effectively. The purposes of this Act are to provide a forum for the effective participation of small businesses in the Federal regulatory process and to clarify and strengthen the Small Business Advocacy. The Small Business Advocacy Review Panel process aims to involve small businesses in the Federal regulatory process effectively. The purposes of this Act include providing a forum for small businesses' participation, clarifying and strengthening the Panel process, and expanding the agencies required to convene Panels. SEC. 3. ENSURING FULL ANALYSIS OF POTENTIAL IMPACTS ON SMALL ENTITIES OF RULES PROPOSED BY CERTAIN AGENCIES. Section 609(b) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to require covered agencies to notify the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publishing an initial regulatory flexibility analysis. This includes providing information on the potential impacts of the proposed rule on small entities. The Chief Counsel must be notified before publishing a regulatory flexibility analysis, providing information on the impacts of the rule on small entities. Within 30 days, affected small entity representatives must be identified and the information transmitted to them. Within 30 days of notifying the Chief Counsel, affected small entity representatives are identified and provided with information for advice on the potential impacts of the draft proposed rule. The head of the covered agency convenes a review panel for the draft proposed rule, consisting of federal employees from the responsible office, the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, and the Chief Counsel, not earlier than 30 days after transmitting information to small entity representatives for advice. The covered agency convenes a review panel for the draft proposed rule, consisting of federal employees from the responsible office, the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, and the Chief Counsel. The panel reviews materials prepared for the proposed rule and gathers advice from small entity representatives. The review panel for the draft proposed rule includes federal employees, the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, and the Chief Counsel. The panel reviews materials, collects advice from small entity representatives, and allows oral presentations. The review panel for the draft proposed rule includes federal employees, the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, and the Chief Counsel. It allows small entity representatives to provide comments and make oral presentations on issues related to specific sections within 60 days. The review panel convenes to report on comments from small entity representatives and findings on specific issues related to sections 603(b) and 603(c). The head of the agency must publish the panel's report in the Federal Register within 120 days of receiving it. The head of the covered agency must publish the review panel's report in the Federal Register within 120 days of receiving it, or as part of the notice of proposed rulemaking. The agency should make appropriate modifications to the draft proposed rule or regulatory analysis as needed. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Amends Section 609(d) of title 5, United States Code to define 'covered agency' as EPA, OSHA, and IRS, and 'small entity representative' as a small entity or its representative. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act takes effect 90 days after enactment.
